Report and Recommendation of the President  
to the Board of Directors
 
 
01111111  
Project Number: 43925 
August 2011 
 
 
Proposed Loan and Partial Risk Guarantee 
Lukoil Overseas Uzbekistan 
Kandym Gas Field Development Project 
 
(Uzbekistan)
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In accordance with ADB’s public communications policy (PCP, 2005), this abbreviated version of the RRP 
excludes confidential information and ADB’s assessment of project or transaction risk as well as other 
information referred to in paragraph 126 of the PCP.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 1 August 2011)

SUM1.00  =  $0.000580 
$1.00  =  SUM1,724 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
      ADB    –  Asian Development Bank 
bcm    –  billion cubic meters 
GPP    –  gas processing plant

LUOC   –  Lukoil Uzbekistan Operating Company 
MIGA    –  Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency 
PRC    –  People’s Republic of China

PSA    –  production sharing agreement 
 
 
NOTES 
(i)  The fiscal year of Lukoil Overseas Uzbekistan ends on 31 December.  
(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  L. Venkatachalam, Private Sector and Cofinancing Operations

Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

1.  Design and Monitoring Framework  11

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan of up to $100 million to Lukoil Overseas Uzbekistan (LOU) and (ii) a partial risk guarantee 
(PRG) of up to $200 million of principal, plus interest and PRG fees, for commercial lenders for 
the Kandym Gas Field Development Project in Uzbekistan. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
1.  Project Identification 
2.  Natural gas is one of the most important export commodities for Uzbekistan and a key 
driver of the economy. In 2010, natural gas exports totaled about $3.5 billion, accounting for 
29% of total exports of goods and services and 10% of the country’s gross domestic product.1 
The Government of Uzbekistan has sought to develop new gas resources to replace its existing 
fields,  where  production  is  declining,  and  to  meet  expected  increased  demand  from  the 
domestic market and the expanding export market. The government plans to develop new 
production and modernization projects valued at a total of $19.4 billion for oil and gas from 2011 
to 2015, of which 85% is expected to be funded by foreign direct investment and external 
loans.2  
 
3.  The Uzbekistan gas subsector is state-controlled and managed through Uzbekneftegaz, 
a national holding company.3 Uzbekneftegaz’s financial resources are not considered adequate 
to meet the significant investment required to fund the growth of the Uzbekistan gas subsector 
and its capacity to develop more technically challenging gas fields may be limited. In recognition 
of these constraints, the government has encouraged major foreign oil and gas operators to 
partner with Uzbekneftegaz and bring in much-needed external capital and expertise to meet 
the development targets of the gas subsector. 
 
4.  Kandym and Khauzak–Shady fields are two large gas fields in the Bukhara–Khiva region 
in the southwestern part of central Uzbekistan. Lukoil Group (Lukoil), a major international oil 
and gas operator, is developing the two fields under a production sharing agreement (PSA). 
Natural gas in these fields has a high sulfur content, which requires a sophisticated drilling and 
desulfurization process. Lukoil will be bringing in state-of-the-art technology to these fields to 
realize environment-friendly and economically efficient gas production. 
 
5.  Lukoil first discussed the project with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in May 2007. 
Lukoil  invited  ADB  to  lead  the  transaction  and  mobilize  the  cofinancing  and  political  risk 
insurance, as no commercial bank has ever lent money to any major gas project in Uzbekistan. 
The proposed project is thus seen as trailblazing, with much wider ramifications for energy and 
infrastructure development and financing in Uzbekistan. To facilitate the participation of ADB 
and commercial banks , the government committed to allowing the sponsor to publicly disclose 
payments made by it under the PSA to the government for the life of the ADB loan (ongoing 
                                                
1  Economic Intelligence Unit. 2011. Country Report Uzbekistan. London.  
2  Resolution of the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan. 2010. On Priority Directions for Industrial Development 
of Uzbekistan for 2011–2015. Tashkent (PP-1442). 
3  Uzbekneftegaz, established in accordance with the edict of the President of Uzbekistan in 1998, is a state-owned 
company involved in all oil and gas businesses in Uzbekistan.

2 
disclosure by the sponsors will be an ongoing condition of the ADB loan). This disclosure will be 
made on an annual basis in English and Uzbek.  
 
2.  Project Design 
6.  The development and production of Kandym and Khauzak–Shady gas fields is governed 
by  a  PSA  signed  in  June  2004  between  the  government  and  a  consortium  of  investors 
comprising LOU and Uzbekneftegaz. The PSA defines the rights and obligations of the various 
parties. LOU is solely responsible for the funding, development, and operation of the two gas 
fields. The cash flows of the Kandym and Khauzak–Shady gas fields will be segregated.  
 
7.  The proceeds of the ADB loan and the PRG-covered commercial loan will only be used 
to finance the Kandym gas field, which is in its development stage. The ADB loan and PRG-
covered commercial loan will be repaid only from the cash flows of Khauzak–Shady gas field 
which is a producing field (gas production started in 2007). The cash flows of Khauzak- Shady 
are considered adequate to service the ADB loan and PRG.  
 
8.  The  Kandym  field  development  program  will  comprise  construction  of  
 production wells, gas collection clusters, a gas-processing plant, ancillary infrastructure, and 
other associated facilities. Khauzak–Shady gas production started in November 2007. LOU 
plans to expand production capacity of Khauzak–Shady field. 
 
9.  The  raw  gas  extracted  from  the  fields  is  transported  through  a  pipeline  to  a  gas 
processing plant (GPP) where the gas is treated to remove sulfur and condensates. The gas 
from Kandym will be processed at a Lukoil-owned GPP that is currently under construction, 
while Khauzak–Shady gas is processed by a government-owned GPP located in Mubarek. The 
processed gas is then transported through government-owned trunk pipelines to the Uzbek 
border with Kazakhstan where the gas is sold to an offtaker (currently Gazprom Export of the 
Russian Federation).  
 
3.  The Borrower 
10.  Borrower. The borrower is LOU, a company registered in the British Virgin Islands and 
an  indirectly,  wholly  owned  subsidiary  of  Lukoil.  LOU  has  formed  two  wholly  owned 
subsidiaries—Lukoil Uzbekistan Operating Company (LUOC) to operate the assets of the PSA, 
and Lukoil Overseas Supply and Trading to market the gas under the PSA.  
 
11.  Lukoil. Lukoil is one of the world’s leading vertically integrated oil and gas companies 
active in exploration and production of oil and gas, production of petroleum products and 
petrochemicals,  and  marketing  of  these  products.  Most  of  the  group's  exploration  and 
production has been based in the Russian Federation, but it has expanded to international 
markets in Africa, Central Asia, and Iraq. Lukoil owns modern refineries, and gas processing 
and petrochemical plants located in the Russian Federation and eastern and western Europe; 
its products are marketed in the Russian Federation, eastern and western Europe, and the 
United States. The parent company of Lukoil (OAO Lukoil) is a publicly listed company on the 
London Stock Exchange and has long-term investment grade ratings from Moody’s (Baa2: 
stable) and Standard & Poor’s (BBB–: stable) as of the end of June 2011.  
 
B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs

3 
1.  Impact 
 
12.  The successful development of Kandym field, a major gas field, will lead to the following 
beyond-project development impacts. First, the overall Uzbekistan gas subsector will expand by 
encouraging foreign operators to develop similar gas reserves and will bring in much-needed 
technical knowledge, development experience, and foreign capital. Second, the increase in gas 
production will lead to an increase in natural gas exports (one of the most important sources of 
export revenue for the country) and opens the possibility of development of the downstream 
petrochemical subsector in Uzbekistan, which uses natural gas as its feedstock. An increase of 
gas resources will also make it viable for Uzbekistan to diversify its export market eastward to 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC)—a pipeline is already in place. Third, the successful 
experience of foreign commercial banks financing a large project in Uzbekistan (a first in the 
Uzbekistan market) is expected to bring in new money from international commercial banks and 
foreign investors. 
 
2.  Outcome 
 
13.  The  outcome  will  be  the  successful  production  of  natural gas  in  Kandym  with first 
production estimated in 2015, with a peak of 8.1 bcm achieved by 2018. The gas produced will 
lead  to  increased  export  revenues  for  Uzbekistan  and  improved  governance  through  the 
disclosure of payments from the project to the government. 
 
3.  Outputs 
 
14.  The outputs will be (i) the development of an environmentally safe,4 technically sound, 
and financially sustainable Kandym field;  (ii) successful mobilization of large-scale cofinancing 
from foreign commercial banks and (iii) increased local employment generation in a relatively 
poor rural area in the Bukhara–Khiva region. The project will meet 80% of its employment needs 
locally with an expected local employment generation of over 7,000 people. The project area is 
a region with high unemployment, increasing migration movements, and low education and 
medical service. One way of improving the socioeconomic environment of the Bukhara region is 
to  attract  external  investment to  provide  employment  opportunities to the  local  population. 
Employment generated by the project will create a large number of opportunities for the citizens 
of Bukhara region and other neighboring provinces. 
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  
 
1.  Consistency with Strategy 2020  
 
15.  Strategy  2020  identifies  the  energy  sector  as  a  core  operations  sector.5Catalyzing 
 
investments by increasing private sector participation in ADB's developing member countries is 
one  of  the  five  strategic  drivers  of  change.  The  project  contributes  to  environmentally 
sustainable growth by enhancing efficient natural resource management in Uzbekistan through 
capacity  development,  technology  deployment,  and  introduction  of  international  safeguard 
standards  and  best  operating  practices. The project  has  the  potential  to  contribute  to the 
promotion of regional integration between the PRC, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan via potential 
                                                
4  The project will employ sophisticated desulfurization technology, which will lead to production of natural gas from 
the high-sulfur gas fields in an environmentally safe manner. 
5  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila.

4 
gas export trades; and could promote usage of relatively more environment-friendly fuel—
natural gas—in the PRC.  
 
2.  Consistency with the Country Strategy  
 
16.  The project is consistent with ADB's country partnership strategy and country operations 
business  plan  for  Uzbekistan,6 which  recognize  the  critical  importance  of  private  sector 
 
development and the need for ADB private sector operations to promote export potential and to 
catalyze foreign investment in infrastructure (including energy). By supporting the project, which 
is sponsored by a private foreign company (Lukoil), ADB will catalyze foreign direct investment 
into the country in a sector with significant export potential.  
 
3.  Consistency with the Energy Policy 
 
17.  The project is consistent with the ADB Energy Policy, which provides for assistance to 
gas field development, and transportation and distribution of gas; encourages private sector 
investment; and promotes effective regional cooperation to strengthen energy security.7  
 
D.  Project Cost and Financing Plan  
18.  The development of the gas fields requires continuous capital expenditure, as new wells 
must be drilled to maintain production to compensate for depleted wells. Kandym field will have 
a field life extending for the next two decades.  
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
19.  Khauzak–Shady is a producing field. The bulk of the capital expenditure required for 
Khauzak–Shady to meet the necessary production volumes are to be made during 2011–2013. 
The project cost estimates are presented in Table 1. The details of the capital expenditure are in 
the details of implementation arrangements.  
Table 1: Project Cost Estimates for 2011–2013  
($ million) 
Item  Kandym  Khauzak–Shady 
Capital expenditure      
  Drilling   100        132 
  Construction  343       185 
  Others    4         8 
Total  447  325 
 Source: Lukoil Overseas Uzbekistan. 
 
20.  The borrower is raising external financing of $500 million for development of the two 
fields. ADB will provide $100 million and the commercial lenders will provide $200 million in loan 
for Kandym field. The commercial loan for Kandym will be covered by ADB’s PRG. The rest of 
the capital expenditure for Kandym over the life of the ADB loan is to be covered by project cash 
flows and Lukoil contributions. The Islamic Development Bank will provide $100 million and the 
commercial lenders will provide $100 million loan for the Khauzak–Shady field. The $100 million 
Islamic Development Bank loan and the $100 million commercial loan are expected to be 
utilized  for  Khauzak–Shady  field  but  would  have  the  flexibility,  if  required,  to  be  used  for 
Kandym field. This commercial loan of $100 million will have PRG cover from the Multilateral

7  ADB. 2009. Energy Policy. Manila.

5 
Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA). The financing plan is in Table 2.  The rest of the capital 
expenditure of Khauzak–Shady over the life of the ADB loan is to be covered by project cash 
flows and Lukoil contributions. 
 
Table 2: Financing Plan for 2011–2013 
($ million)

Source: Lukoil Overseas Uzbekistan. 
 
21.  The external financing being raised represents only a portion of the total funds required 
to fully exploit all the recoverable reserves of the fields covered under the PSA. To meet the 
large scale of investment required, in addition to providing its own funds, the borrower may raise 
a new round of external financing in the future. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  Table 3 summarizes the implementation arrangements. 
 
Table 3: Summary of Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Regulatory  The PSA is the main governing document that defines the rights and obligations of the 
framework  contractual parties in relation to the exploration, development, and production of the 
gas assets. The PSA, among other things, gives the borrower the right to access 
transportation infrastructure and gas processing capacity, sell gas into the export 
market, and convert currency.  
  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED  
Implementation  The disbursement period for all loans is expected to be 18 months, currently estimated 
period  from fourth quarter 2011 to first quarter 2013. 
Operations  LUOC is responsible for project operations (based on the joint operating agreement 
arrangements  between LOU and Uzbekneftegaz). 
Operation and  LUOC  will  be responsible for operation and maintenance  in  accordance  with the

6 
F.  Projected Financial and Economic Performance 
23.  The Kandym gas field project is financially viable and  is economically sustainable as the 
economic internal rate of return is  higher than the social discount rate. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
A.  The Assistance 
24.  The proposed ADB loan of up to $100 million to LOU to finance the development of 
Kandym gas field will be provided from ADB’s ordinary capital resources without government 
guarantee. The ADB loan will have a maximum term of up to 8 years, including a grace period 
of 18 months and will be repaid quarterly. The ADB loan will carry an interest rate as well as 
other fees to be approved by ADB’s investment committee.  
 
25.  The proposed PRG of up to $200 million principal, plus interest and PRG fees, to 
commercial  lenders  will  cover  a  loan  from  commercial  lenders  to  the  borrower  to  finance 
development of Kandym gas field. The PRG will have a tenor of up to 7 years and match the 
tenor of the loan from commercial lenders. Under the PRG, ADB will assume the risks of 
currency inconvertibility, nontransferability of funds, war, terrorism and political violence, and 
breach of contract (arbitration award default and denial of recourse) on the guaranteed portion 
of  the  commercial  lenders’  loan.  The  guaranteed  lenders  are  expected  to  comprise  BNP 
Paribas,  Crédit  Agricole  Corporate  and  Investment  Bank,  Korea  Development  Bank,  and 
UniCredit Bank. They are eligible under applicable ADB policies as they relate to beneficiaries 
of credit enhancement products. The PRG will carry a guarantee fee as well as other fees and 
terms to be approved by ADB’s investment committee. ADB’s maximum aggregate liability 
under the PRG will be up to $225 million.8 A portion of the PRG may be syndicated through 
reinsurance contracts to counterparties that are eligible under existing ADB policies. 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
26.  ADB assistance adds value in the following ways:  
(i)  The ADB loan will play a leading catalytic role as it facilitates, for the first time in 
Uzbekistan,  the  raising  of  large-scale,  long-term,  commercial  financing  from 
international  commercial  banks.  The  successful  financing  of  the  project  will 
prompt  future  raising  of  much-needed  commercial  capital  for  the  general 
development of the gas subsector and other infrastructure projects in Uzbekistan.  
(ii)  The ADB PRG is essential for the raising of cofinancing as it (along with the 
MIGA guarantee) covers the political risks that commercial lenders are currently 
not willing to directly absorb. The PRG extended by ADB allows the project to 
raise cost-effective commercial cofinancing.  
(iii)  ADB’s presence in the transaction reduces the overall political risk of the project, 
which provides reassurance to the foreign sponsor.  
(iv)  The  participation  of  ADB  has  been  instrumental  in  the  public  disclosure  of 
payments received by the government under the PSA for the life of the ADB loan. 
                                                
8  The maximum aggregate liability is the maximum amount of principal plus interest and PRG fees that ADB can be 
held liable for under the PRG should a guaranteed event occur and ADB exercises its right to pay the lenders the 
guaranteed portion of principal and interest on scheduled payment dates.

7 
This  is  considered  to  be  an  important  step  forward  by  the  government  in 
promoting transparency for the project; overall it sends a very positive signal to 
the market.  
(v)  The introduction of ADB’s environment and social safeguards will improve overall 
soundness of the project.  
(vi)  The project will be the first private sector infrastructure project financed by ADB 
in Uzbekistan and broadens ADB’s relationship with the country. The project also 
strengthens  ADB’s  relationship  with  key  development  partners—the  Islamic 
Development Bank and MIGA. 
 
C.  Risks  
27.  The transaction follows a reserve-based lending structure for upstream gas financing, 
which is common in the project financing markets.  
 
28.  Offtake risk. The gas produced from Khauzak–Shady field is currently sold to Gazprom 
Export  (wholly  owned  subsidiary  of  the  Russian  gas  company,  JSC  Gazprom)  through 
Uztransgaz at the gas sale delivery point at the Kazakhstan–Uzbekistan border. The project is 
exposed to market risk since gas volume and price are not underpinned by a long-term offtake 
contract. The term of the gas sale contract has historically been limited to 1 year but so far, 
renewed every year. The gas sale price is the standard market price received for all gas sales 
from Uzbekistan to the Russian Federation. The gas sale price is in US dollars based on a 
formula linked to European gas prices. LOU is negotiating for a longer-term sales contract with 
Gazprom and is considering potential sales to the PRC.  
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED  
 
29.  Political, legal, and regulatory risk. The transaction is exposed to Uzbek political, legal, 
and regulatory risk. These risks are perceived to be high in Uzbekistan. Foreign investment and 
project financing is a  relatively new area in Uzbekistan with very few precedents and the 
government  is  unfamiliar  with  it.  The  country's  legal  and  regulatory  structure  as  well  as 
enforceability of security arrangements remains untested. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED  
 
30.  Development  and  operations  risk.  Lukoil  has  experience  in  the  development  and 
operation of gas fields in Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan, with extensive experience in 
the  Russian  Federation.  Specifically  LOU  over  the  past  seven  years  has  demonstrated  a 
successful track record in operating and developing gas fields under the PSA in Uzbekistan. 
The lenders’ debt service will be paid from the cash flows of the Khauzak–Shady field, which 
has been producing gas since 2007. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
31.  Reservoir  risk.  The  independent  gas  reserves  report  of  Miller  and  Lents  and  the 
lenders’ technical bank9 has verified the adequacy of proven gas reserves. The fact that lenders’ 
debt service will be paid from the cash flows of the Khauzak–Shady field (a producing field) also 
mitigates the reservoir risk.  
  
                                                
9 Technical bank is the bank which is advising the consortium of lenders on technical matters like gas reservoir.

8 
32.  Gas processing and transportation risk. The gas produced at Khauzak–Shady field is 
processed at Mubarek GPP, a government-owned plant. The GPP has been operating for over 
30 years and in 1996 enhanced its annual processing capacity to 30 bcm. The Mubarek GPP 
has been running successfully and processes about 50% of all the natural gas in Uzbekistan; 
with Khauzak–Shady field accounting for 10% of its total capacity, it has capacity to absorb 
increased production from Khauzak–Shady field. The pipeline-quality gas that emerges from the 
Mubarek GPP is transported to the Kazakhstan–Uzbekistan border through the Central Asia–
Center pipeline with a capacity of 50 bcm. The pipeline is owned by Uztransgaz, the national 
pipeline company, and has been running well with ample capacity to absorb any new potential 
gas production. Another option in the future is to ship the gas using the Central Asia–PRC 
pipeline. The PSA guarantees the priority right of LOU to process raw gas from Khauzak–Shady 
field at the Mubarek GPP and guarantees unrestricted access to the system of trunk and local 
gas pipelines in Uzbekistan.  
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
33.  Cash flow risk. The lenders’ base case scenario, which is more conservative than the 
sponsor’s base case scenario, shows that cash flows are robust enough to allow the full debt 
amount.  
 
IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Safeguard and Social Dimensions  
34.  The  project  is  classified  under  environment  category  A,  involuntary  resettlement 
category B, and indigenous peoples category C under the Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
The potential environmental and social impacts and risks of the project have been identified and 
effective measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the adverse impacts are 
incorporated  in  the  environmental  impact  assessment.  All  prior  land  acquisitions  were 
undertaken in accordance with the Safeguard Policy Statement as documented in the ADB 
social safeguards compliance audit report.10 The final alignment of the project railway, gas 
pipelines,  field  access  roads,  and  transmission  line  have  not  yet  been  prepared;  thus,  a 
resettlement framework was prepared and disclosed on the ADB website.11 These areas are 
sparsely populated and the landscape is vast and mostly uninhabited arid desert land; therefore, 
land acquisition for these facilities is expected to have limited or no impact. The institutional 
capacity and commitment of LOU to manage the project’s social and environmental risks are 
deemed  adequate.  Information  disclosure  and  consultations  with  affected  people  were 
conducted in accordance with ADB requirements. The draft environmental impact assessment 
was made publicly available in June 2010 and the revised assessment was posted on the ADB 
website in May 2011 in line with the Safeguard Policy Statement.12 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy  
35.  The borrower has been advised of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to 
date) and its policy of implementing best international practice relating to the combating of 
money  laundering  and  the  financing  of  terrorism.    ADB  will  ensure  that  the  project 
                                                
10 Social Safeguards Compliance Audit Report  (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
11  ADB. 2010. Safeguard Policy Statement. Operations Manual. OM F1/OP. Manila (para. 51). 
12  Environmental Impact Assessment;  Resettlement Framework; Safeguards and Social Dimensions Summary; 
Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
documentation includes appropriate anti-corruption provisions and remedies for ADB in the 
event of non-compliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations  
36.  The proposed direct loan and PRG are within the country, industry, group, and single 
project exposure limits for nonsovereign investments.  
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED  
 
D.  Assurances 
37.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank,  the 
Government of Uzbekistan will be requested to confirm that it has no objection to the proposed 
assistance to LOU. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance 
satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed assistance by the Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
38.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan and partial risk guarantee (PRG) would comply with 
the Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the 
Board approve (i) the loan of $100,000,000 to Lukoil Overseas Uzbekistan; and (ii) the PRG of 
$200,000,000 principal, plus interest and PRG fees for commercial lenders for the Kandym Gas 
Field Development Project in Uzbekistan from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with such 
terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and 
as may be reported to the Board. 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 
 
 
10 August 2011

author_page:
CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 1 August 2011) 
Currency unit  –  sum (SUM) 
SUM1.00  =  $0.000580 
$1.00  =  SUM1,724 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
      ADB    –  Asian Development Bank 
bcm    –  billion cubic meters 
GPP    –  gas processing plant 
LOU    –  Lukoil Overseas Uzbekistan 
LUOC   –  Lukoil Uzbekistan Operating Company 
MIGA    –  Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency 
PRC    –  People’s Republic of China 
PRG    –  partial risk guarantee 
PSA    –  production sharing agreement 
 
 
NOTES 
(i)  The fiscal year of Lukoil Overseas Uzbekistan ends on 31 December.  
(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  L. Venkatachalam, Private Sector and Cofinancing Operations 
Director General  P. Erquiaga, Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) 
Director  M. Barrow, Infrastructure Division 1, PSOD 
   
Team leaders  S. Shah, Senior Investment Specialist, PSOD 
H. Hoshi, Investment Specialist, PSOD

Resident Mission

M. Manabat, Senior Investment Officer, PSOD  
J. Munsayac, Safeguards Specialist, PSOD

S. Wermert, Principal Investment Specialist, PSOD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
